bibl.title: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Joseph H. White, March 26, 1925

div1.p: Carr sends White his clinical history and autopsy report on a Brazilian yellow fever case and describes several other cases.

div1.head: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Joseph H. White, March 26, 1925
div1.opener:

1.

Carr to White

From Dr G J Carr
to Dr White
March 26th, 1925.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honour to submit the enclosed report of the autopsy on
Robert Sherman, the second case of Yellow Fever which has died in Parahyba
during this month.

I am also enclosing the letters of the President which are self-explanatory
and show the cooperation which exists between the Authorities and the
Officials of the Board, as represented by the Commission in this State.
Already, as you know, scouting has been done by Dr. Bião in Itabayanna
who will proceed to Campina Grande to continue his work, but the real
offensive will be launched on Monday the 30th, by myself and Mr. Cabral
in both cities.

By consulting the map it can be seen that Itabayanna is the key position
on the direct line, Recife---Parahyba---Campina Grande, while Campina
Grande is the key position to the entire central portion of the state.
By an effective barrage being established at those points and Parahyba
(Capital) I am of the opinion that infection can be prevented from spreading
northward. As you have heard from Mr. Tebyricá, he has taken stringent measures
to protect Natal, but I shall shortly include that city in my round of in-
spections and make further report.

Taking as a basis for my epidemiological study the findings og the “Yellow
Fever Commission” to Quayaquil as reprinted from the “Journal of Experimental
Medicine” June 1st, 1919, the following are the facts of the movements
of the three reported cases in Parahyba and Recife, of the case reported from
Triumpho in the State of Pernambuco I have no details but shall get them in
due course.
COPY
O'Donnell. 1st case.

He was in Recife during the nights of February 22nd, 23rd, 24th, arriving
there on the evening of the 22nd, and leaving the morning of the 25th,
his movements there are in your hands.

In Parahyba the evening of the 25th, and that night slept in the Luzo-Brasi-
leiro Hotel where he had had his room since December 1924.

He proceeded to Alagôa Grande on the 27th, and slept there in the Hotel Né
Costa returning to Parahyba on the afternoon of the 28th.

From that time until his death he slept in the Luzo in Parahyba and remained
in this city with the exception of the two hours which he spent in Itabayanna
on March the 1st, not including the time spent on the journey.

As you have read in my previous report his foreman states that he complained
in Alagôa Grande of “headache” and pains in the body" (27th-28th).

He was ill enough to stop work on the day of March 3rd, and was acutely
ill that night.

Within these dates, taking the incubation period as from 3 to 6 days, he
might have got his infection:
In Recife.
In Parahyba.
In Alagôa Grande (this place least likely).

It must be remembered however the biting habits of the Aedes aegypti and
consider the fact that the train stops for some time at Itabayanna during
its passage from Recife from which place he travelled on the day of the
25th, and being an official of the railroad he might have been in the
station house, this they could not remember.

div1.p:
This case was, if a true one, very light, I myself saw her on the 13th,
with no symptoms and the history of her medical attendants is both
contradictory and, in the case of her urine, false in the second examination,
and I was told her Doctor had never seen a case previously, while I am
convinced that the Doctors of the Prophylaxia Rural are not competent to
diagnose so light a case.

Furthermore a report of her blood taken by Dr. Bião and sent to Bahia was
returned “Negative”, this latter however must be taken with due regard
to the period of the disease and the known percentage of failures with
a clear clinical picture.
Sherman 3rd case.

This man arrived in Parahyba on the early morning of the 16th, complaining
of a “headache.”

On the 17th, he sent for a Doctor, the rest of his clinical history I have
already reported.

He had arrived in Itabayanna on the 16th, about noon and remained there in
the Hotel Avenida until 2 a.m. on the morning of the 16th, when he took
train for Parahyba, arriving about 7 a.m.

He had stayed in the “Recife Hotel” Recife from the 9th to the 12th.
according to an inquiry from the Director in Recife.
(From 4th-9th in Hotel Boa Vista, Recife.)

This case is more definite, within these dates he might have got his infection in,
Recife,

Taking all three,
The lines of O'Donnell and the Gerifs case cross at Itabayanna and Parahyba.
The lines of Gerifs and Sherman cross at Itabayanna.

The lines of Sherman and O'Donnell cross at Recife and Itabayanna. (The latter
for two hours only in the case of O'Donnell).
PROVISIONAL DEDUCTIONS.

Itabayanna would appear by the case of Sherman to be the most likely place
in terms of the minimum incubation period, and in the case of O'Donnell
Parahyba.

Recife, in the case of Sherman and O'Donnell in terms of the longer incubation
while, Itabayanna in the former terms and Parahyba in the latter for the case
of Gerifs.
Parahyba.
No cases reported for several years.
The index for the last 6 months.

The fact that both O'Donnell and the Gerifs woman had been living in the
same hotel and pensão previously, the former since December, the latter
since February 8th to 20th. (vide previous report).
Itabayanna.

An apparently confirmed death from Yellow Fever in May 1924 which had not
been away from Itabayanna for two months previous to his death. The diagnosis
however was not that of Yellow Fever at the time, and only now does the
Doctor admit that it had the typical symptoms, this must be taken for what
it is worth. No further suspicious cases are admitted to have occurred
5.
either before or after this case.
Known cases in the spring of 1924.

Known cases in the small towns along the lines of the Great Western Railroad
together with actual epidemics in Caruaru and Alagoa de Monteiro and their
immediate neighborhood, (vide previous reports.)

The great influx of “Carnavalistas” at these particular times after which
cases began to appear outside as well as inside Recife. (previous report)
The index.
No cases have been reported since April 1924.

At the moment of writing no cases have been reported in Parahyba, which
indicates that apparently the mosquitoes or mosquito which may have bitten
either O'Donnell or Gerifs and caused their infection were not encountered
here, while any which bit O'Donnell during his first three days, provided
any did so, have not yielded secondary cases.

Neither Dr. Bião nor myself have been able to trace any cases in Itabayanna
I have not yet had time to examine Timbauba but this town would appear to
be ruled out by the dates.

The Director of Recife has not reported any further suspicious cases having
been reported to him.

As is well known up until the present the authorities of this district
generally have made it difficult to get accurate reports of cases but I
am glad to think that now they realize the urgency and, at least in Parahyba,
will be more frank and cooperative.

I regret to say that, according to hearsay evidence, the Prophylaxia Rural
is not in a position to give much assistance but at the present time we
have established friendly and cordial relations, which I have always taken
6
care to pursue.

With the President behind us I think I am justified in expecting a full
measure of success in our new work and renewed vigor in our old endeavours.

I have the honour to be
Sir
